sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on Gettysburg & Vicksburg. Turning Point (1863). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Sarah, age 15, from Gettysburg, 1863.

sections.section: Chapter 1: Our Town Becomes a Battlefield
sections.narration: I'm Sarah, fifteen years old, and I live in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania. It's a small town—just 2,400 people—where ten roads meet. We have a Lutheran seminary, a college, farms, shops. It's a peaceful place.
visuals: Chapter title: Our Town Becomes a Battlefield
sections.key_takeaway: I'm Sarah, fifteen years old, and I live in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania.

sections.narration: July 2. The second day of battle was even more terrible than the first. The fighting shifted south to the Round Tops—rocky, wooded hills at the end of the Union line. From our cellar, we heard continuous artillery fire.
visuals: Chapter title: Day Two—Little Round Top

sections.narration: July 3, 1863. The third day of battle. The day Gettysburg became the war's turning point. The morning was relatively quiet—just scattered skirmishing.
July 4. Lee's army began retreating to Virginia. The Battle of Gettysburg was over. The Confederacy had lost.

The same day Lee retreated from Gettysburg—July 4, 1863—another momentous victory occurred a thousand miles away. Vicksburg, Mississippi, surrendered to General Ulysses S. Grant after a 47-day siege. We learned about it days later through the newspapers.
visuals: Chapter title: Vicksburg—The River Runs Free
sections.key_takeaway: The same day Lee retreated from Gettysburg—July 4, 1863—another momentous victory occurred a thousand miles away.

sections.narration: In this lesson, we explored Gettysburg & Vicksburg through 5 chapters. Key concepts included: Battle of Gettysburg, Pickett's Charge, Gettysburg Address, Siege of Vicksburg.
